_exec_summary.SummaryText:
July 19, 2005 Revision-2

April 29, 2005

June 17, 2004 Previous Submission Date 

26907 LDEQ Facility ID Number

   The United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) developed the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68)to assist facilities in preventing accidental releases of highly toxic or flammable chemicals.  The RMP established three levels of requirements for the program.  Programs 1 and 2 are for facilities that pose less risk to the environment and therefore have reduced compliance requirements.  Program 1 is designed for no impact facilities and has the fewest requirements, while Program 3 is the most stringent of the three levels.

   The program level for each facility is determined by:
   Use of regulated substances in threshold quantity
   Impact of an off-site public receptor (e.g., residence, school, park)
   North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code
   Five-year accident history
   OHSA PSM (29 CFR 1910.119) applicability. 

   As of July 19, 2005, Delta Terminal Services remains regulated under Program 2 requirements under 40 CFR 68.10 because:
The facility currently stores toluene 2, 4-diisocyanate, Chloroform, Cyclohexylamine and Epichlorohydrin in excess of the threshold quantities.
   
   Therefore, a release from this facility could impact an offsite public Receptors such as a residence and school.  The facility does not operate under a NAICS code specified in the rule and it is not subject to OSHA PSM because PSM does not apply to flammable liquids stored in atmospheric tanks which are kept below their normal boiling point without benefit of chilling or refrigeration [29 CFR 1926.64(a)(1)(ii)(B)].).  In addition, none of the toxic chemicals meet the Progran 3 criteria as they are not a listed OSHA PSM chemical.

   The regulation, 40 CFR Part 68 Subpart G, applies to an owner or operator of a stationary source that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under

40 CFR 68.115, Delta Terminal Services stores more than the threshold quantity of toluene 2, 4-diisocyanate (10,000 pounds); chloroform (20,000 pounds), cyclohexylamine (15,000 pounds) and Epichlorohydrin (20,000 pounds).

   The plan was originally submitted by June 20, 1999, updated in November of 2000 and in June and July of 2001, to include additional storage for toluene 2, 4-diisocyanate (TDI).  In addiition, on June 17, 2004, a 5 Year re-submittal was completed which updated the RMP by including inventory for Drum storage, potential railcars and tanktrucks onsite, a 5 year accident history, updated emergency contact informatiom and removal of the OCA from the executive summary.  Delta was last required to submit an updated RMP, Revision 1 to cover cyclohexylamine on April 29, 2005.  The purpose of Revision 2, dated July 19, 2005, is to correct data submitted in revision 1, apply new modeling for TDI using EPA's RMPComp software and cover Epichlorohydrin. 

   Delta Terminal Services remains committed to operating in a safe and compliant manner. Employees involved in operating the TDI, Chloroform and Cyclohexylamine activities are thoroughly trained to identify and understand the hazards posed by these transfer processes.  Process safety and emergency response materials are kept on site and periodically reviewed.  Materials include information pertaining to the hazards of TDI, Chloroform, Cyclohexylamine and Epichlorohydrin, process technology, process equipment, and emergency response procedures.

   The Stationary Sources for Cyclohexylamine, TDI and Chloroform are storage tanks and related appurtenances.  The stationary source for Epichlorohydrin are iso-containers.

   The largest Cyclohexylamine single process group is storage tank 120-11, with a storage capacity of 504,000 gallons at 7.22 lbs/gal or 3,638,880 pounds. 

   The largest single TDI process group (e.g., largest storage tank or group of interconnected tanks) is storage tank 350-11 with a stora

ge capacity of 1,444,473 gallons at 10.16 lbs/gal or 14,675,846 pounds.  The total TDI aggregate stationary storage tank capacity is approximately 53,000,000 pounds.  

   The largest Chloroform process group is storage tank 350-10 with a capacity of 1,442,870 gallons at 12.49 lbs/gal or 18,021,446 pounds. 

   The largest Epichlorohydrin process group is an is-container with a capacity of 27,000 pounds.  We do not anticipate having more than 4 iso-containers onsite at any one time.


In addition to aforementioned stationary storage tanks, the following can be present onsite:
2 Cyclohexylamine Railcars and 1 Cyclohexylamine Tank truck;
20 TDI Railcars and 5,800 TDI 55 gallon drums;
1Chloroform Tank truck and 80 Chloroform Drums.   
  
   The total other inventory quantity for Cyclohexylamnie is:
2 Railcars at 22,000 gals each is 44,000 gals at 7.22 lbs/gal or 317,680 pounds.
1 Tank truck at 6,300 gals. or 45,486 pounds.
Total Other Cyclohexylamine = 363,166 pounds.

   The total other inventory quantity for TDI is:
20 railcars at 190,000 lbs. each or 3,800,000 pounds.
5,800 TDI drums at 55 gals each is 319,000 gallons at 10.16 lbs/gal. or 3,241,040 pounds.
Total Other TDI = 7,041,040 pounds.

   The total other inventory for Chloroform is:
1 chloroform tanktruck or 6,300 gallons at 12.49 lbs/gal or 78,687 pounds
80 chloroform drums at 55 gals each or 54,956 pounds.
Total Other Chloroform = 113,643 pounds. 

                                                                      Inventory Summary

   Maximum Pounds Cyclohexylamine = 4,000,000               120-11  Worse Case Process Rounded to 4,000,000 Lbs.
   Maximum Pounds TDI                     = 60,400,000              350-11 Worse Case Process Rounded to 15,000,000 Lbs.
   Maximum Pounds Chloroform          = 18,100,000              350-10 Worse Case Process Rounded to 18,000,000 Lbs.
   Maximum Pounds Epichlorohydrin   =  108,000                  4- iso-containers Worse Case Process Rounded to 100,000 Lbs.

The above Inventory Summary totals are rounded up, as required by the RMPComp software.

   The facility is required to complete one worst-case release scenario per hazardous substance handled [68.165(a)(2)] to determine program applicability.  Delta Terminal had originally chosen in 1999 to use the DEGADIS+ and Chloroform Evaporating Pool Model [as described in the article  The Evaporation of Volatile Liquids (Hazardous Materials vol 15, pg 343-364] release models to determine offsite impacts.  In the revision dated April 12, 2005, Delta chose RMPComp to determine the endpoint for Cyclohexylamine, which becomes the newest worst case scenario.  Now, in Revision 2, dated July 1, 2005 Delta has chose RMPComp to model TDI and Epichlorohydrin.  

   Railcar, truck and drum warehouseing activity is not considered in determining the RMP worst case release scenario; only storage tanks were used.

   The facility maintains written process safety information to enable employees involved in handling Cyclohexylamine, TDI and Chloroform to identify and understand the hazards posed by these processes. Written information includes physical properties of Cyclohexylamine, TDI, Chloroform and Epichlorohydrin, health risks associated with exposure and material safety data sheets.

   In addition, the facility has conducted and/or implemented the following:
          
             hazards review
             standard operating procedures
             training program
             maintenance program
             compliance audits
             incident investigation     

   Delta Terminal Services, had 4 recordable accidents within the 5 years prior to the first resubmittal of the plan, in 2004, for toluene 2, 4-diisocyanate and chloroform.  There have been no additional recordable accidents since the last submittal of this plan, to date. 
         
  Previously, recommendations for safety improvements were identified in the hazard review which was first completed April 20, 1999, an

d  identified for two categories: Standard Operating Procedures, and Training.
  
  Safety improvements will be investigated concerning their impacts on other systems and/or procedures prior to implementation.

   Additional recommendations will continue to be made upon review of any accidents and/or when the hazard review is updated or every five years, which ever occurs first.
